title: Egypt's Morsi sentenced to death
desc: An Egyptian court sentences ousted president Mohammed Morsi to death over a mass prison break in 2011.

title: US special forces in Syria raid
desc: US special forces have killed an Islamic State commander with a key role in oil and gas operations in a rare raid in eastern Syria, the Pentagon says.

title: Russian rocket burns up over Siberia
desc: A Russian rocket carrying a Mexican satellite malfunctions and burns up over Siberia soon after launch on Saturday, Russia's space agency says.

title: Migrant boats 'not a Myanmar problem'
desc: Myanmar's government says it is not responsible for the migrant boat crisis in south-east Asia, and may not attend an emergency summit on the issue.

title: Two dead in German train crash
desc: At least two people have been killed and 20 injured in western Germany after a train collided with a tractor-trailer on a level crossing, police say.

title: IS tightens grip on Iraq's Ramadi
desc: Islamic State fighters tighten their grip on the centre of the Iraqi city of Ramadi after repelling an advance by government forces.

title: Burundi crackdown after coup bid
desc: Eighteen people appear in court in Burundi as the government begins a crackdown against those suspected of involvement in a failed coup.

title: Death sentence for Boston bomber
desc: Boston Marathon bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev is sentenced to death over the 2013 attack that killed three people and injured 260.

title: US 'concern' over China sea actions
desc: US Secretary of State John Kerry expresses concern over China's actions in disputed waters in the South China Sea, while on a visit to Beijing.

title: Bodies recovered at Nepal crash site
desc: The charred bodies of six American marines and two Nepali soldiers are recovered from the site of a US helicopter crash in Nepal, officials say.

title: Man blinded in one eye by Miller six
desc: An Indian policeman has been blinded in one eye after being hit by a David Miller six during an Indian Premier League match.

title: Church votes to allow gay ministers
desc: The General Assembly of the Church of Scotland votes to allow congregations to ordain gay ministers who are in same sex civil partnerships.

title: VIDEO: The unknown fate of desperate boat migrants
desc: The BBC's Jonathan Head has been following the fate of one boat of migrants

title: VIDEO: Reprisal attack for Burundi coup bid
desc: The BBC's Karen Allen sees evidence of retaliatory attacks in Burundi, aimed at those accused of being behind last week's failed coup attempt.

title: VIDEO: Ukraine: Will ban on Soviet symbols change how people think?
desc: Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko signs into law legislation that bans the use of communist symbols.

title: VIDEO: Auschwitz survivor testifies at trial
desc: When Susan Pollack was 13, she was sent to the concentration camp at Auschwitz, where more than one million people, mostly Jews, were killed by the Nazis during the Second World War.

title: VIDEO: Hopes for new leads in Ben Needham case
desc: The mother of missing Ben Needham has made a new appeal on Greek television over the disappearance of her son 24 years ago.

title: VIDEO: Women in spotlight at Cannes festival
desc: The subject of women's roles in the world of cinema has been in the spotlight at the 2015 Cannes Film Festival.

title: VIDEO: Spending the night with robots
desc: The BBC's Zoe Kleinman stays overnight at a home packed with different types of robots and sensors in London.

title: VIDEO: Musical ties that bind US and Cuba
desc: The Minnesota Orchestra is preparing to play in Havana, the first US orchestra to visit the island since relations began to improve last December.

title: Boston in shock over Tsarnaev death penalty
desc: The BBC's Tara McKelvey in Boston looks at the reaction to the death sentence imposed on marathon bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev.

title: Why India’s government is targeting Greenpeace
desc: Some fear that PM Narendra Modi may compromise India's core values in his effort to transform the country's economy, writes Justin Rowlatt.

title: Take N Korea tales with a bucket of salt
desc: What should we make of the reports that North Korean Defence Minister, Hyon Yong-chol, was purged and executed by anti-aircraft gunfire?

title: Why test women's virginity for the army?
desc: Indonesia is being urged to stop so-called virginity tests for female military recruits, but why are they doing them and who else does?

title: VIDEO: How Amtrak crash could have been averted
desc: Following the fatal crash of an Amtrak train in Philadelphia, the spotlight is once again on the Positive Train Control (PTC) system. Here's how it works.

title: Why are so many Rohingya migrants stranded at sea?
desc: The background to the plight of thousands of Rohingya Muslim refugees from Myanmar believed to be stranded off the coasts of Thailand and Malaysia.

title: McConaughey brushes off Cannes 'boos'
desc: Oscar-winning actor Matthew McConaughey shrugs off criticism of his new film at the Cannes film festival ahead of Saturday's public premiere.

title: David Lynch rejoins Twin Peaks show
desc: Film Director David Lynch announces that he will direct the sequel of the cult classic Twin Peaks after a month-long deadlock over budget concerns.

title: Russian economy shrinks as woes mount
desc: Low oil prices and weak spending force the Russian economy to shrink in the first quarter.

title: S Africa miners 'fail' black rules
desc: South Africa's mining industry tells the government a dispute over claims that companies have failed black ownership rules will be settled in court.

title: Blizzard tackles Warcraft 'cheats'
desc: Thousands of World of Warcraft accounts have been shut down by Blizzard as it moves to stop people using 'bots' to play the game

title: Public test for Google robot cars
desc: Google's purpose-built robot cars are getting the green light to drive on public roads in California.

title: King of Blues BB King dies at 89
desc: 'King of the Blues' legend BB King dies in Las Vegas aged 89, his lawyer says.

title: Allen TV show 'a catastrophic mistake'
desc: Woody Allen says the new TV series he is creating for Amazon could be a cosmic embarrassment.

title: Arctic pollution rules 'not enough'
desc: New guidelines are passed to prevent pollution from ships passing through polar waters, but environmentalists are calling for tougher measures.

title: Warm-blooded fish traps its own heat
desc: The deep-water opah becomes the first fish known to regulate its own temperature, using heat from its flapping fins to warm its heart and brain.

title: Heart screens 'needed for athletes'
desc: Olympic athletes should have tailored heart screening to check for life-threatening conditions before they can compete, a leading Italian doctor says.

title: Exercise 'buys five years for elderly'
desc: Regular exercise in old age has as powerful an effect on life expectancy as giving up smoking, a study suggests.

title: Djokovic into Italian Open final
desc: World number one Novak Djokovic beats Spain's David Ferrer 6-4 6-4 to reach his sixth Italian Open final.

title: Liverpool 1-3 Crystal Palace
desc: Steven Gerrard's final game for Liverpool at Anfield ends in a humbling defeat by Crystal Palace.

title: The metal that brought you cheap flights
desc: Air travel is affordable partly because jet engines are efficient - and for that the world must thank a cheap dull metal that helps makes some superalloys.

title: Hamburger icon: How these three lines mystify most people
desc: The hamburger button has become a common symbol on our smartphones, tablets and computers. But what is it?

title: Colombian bishop offends both sides
desc: A Roman Catholic bishop in Colombia manages to offend both conservative believers and the gay community at a conference on gay marriage and adoption.

title: 'Slow TV' lambing for Iceland viewers
desc: Icelandic TV shows 24 hours of sheep giving birth.

title: Ex-Bin Laden aide sentenced to life
desc: Ex-aide to Osama Bin Laden, Khalid al-Fawwaz, is sentenced to life in US prison for 1998 US embassy bombings in east Africa that killed 224 people.

title: India and China sign $22bn in deals
desc: India signs trade and economic co-operation deals worth $22bn ($14bn) in Shanghai as PM Narendra Modi's visit to China draws to a close.

title: New leads in missing toddler case
desc: Detectives searching for missing Ben Needham say an appeal by his family on Greek television has generated several possible leads.

title: DNA resolves US-Mexico custody case
desc: A teenage girl at the centre of a US-Mexico custody battle is to be reunited with her mother in Texas after DNA tests confirmed her identity.

title: Heavy fighting at ancient Syria site
desc: Syrian government forces try to drive back Islamic State militants from the ancient ruins of Palmyra, one of the archaeological jewels of the Middle East.

title: Amtrak train 'may have been struck'
desc: The Amtrak train that derailed in Philadelphia on Tuesday may have been hit by an object shortly before the crash, a US investigator says.

title: Scots Labour leader Murphy to resign
desc: Scottish Labour leader Jim Murphy announces he is to resign next month despite narrowly surviving a vote of no confidence.

title: Labour contenders clash on spending
desc: The contenders for the leadership of the Labour Party clash over the party's record in government, including public spending, in a public debate.

title: Co-op Group to keep political funding
desc: The Co-operative Group decides to continue financially supporting the Co-operative Party, which has strong ties to Labour.

title: Osborne plans July 'stability' Budget
desc: Chancellor George Osborne says he will deliver a new Budget on 8 July which will entrench stability and security and raise living standards.
